awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in DRMS: Investigating Environmental Justice and Managing Air Pollution Risk through Participatory Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Some people have turned to non- governmental air quality monitoring networks (NAQMNs) to assess their air pollution exposures. NAQMNs include low-cost, networked air pollution sensors hosted at homes and schools that display real-time pollutant concentrations on publicly accessible websites. The self-organizing nature of NAQMNs may produce a highly uneven spatial distribution of sensors, and barriers to acquiring sensors may systemically disenfranchise some social groups. This is important because air pollution exposure causes negative health effects and exposures tend to vary based on race/ethnicity and socioeconomic status. The overall goal of this project is to assess how families with children with asthma use the sensors while expanding the Salt Lake County, Utah NAQMN. Without equal access to air pollution information, the public cannot stay adequately informed, which in turn may affect their perceptions and actions concerning pollution exposure and health. This project is relevant to environmental policy nationally, and in Salt Lake County, which often exceeds national pollution standards. Adding 20 sensors in areas of greatest need will enhance equity in Salt Lake County’s NAQMN. The researcher recruits a student from a historically underrepresented group as a research assistant and disseminates findings via multiple outlets, including by publishing articles in top-tier journals and sharing findings with NAQMN managers, study participants, and policymakers. 

This project aims to: (1) assess socio-spatial inequalities in the distribution of a NAQMN in Salt Lake County; and (2) use those results to select local environmental justice communities of concern with sparse NAQMN coverage in order to examine how participatory air quality sensing shapes residents’ understandings and decisions. The research first uses statistical analyses to assess whether sensors in the NAQMN (n=249) are unevenly distributed with respect to race/ethnicity and socioeconomic status at the census tract level (n=236) and identifies tracts in ‘high need’ of sensors. Next, the researcher recruits 20 families without sensors who live in the ‘high need’ areas and 10 families that already have sensors as a comparison group. He provides sensors connected to the NAQMN to the 20 families without sensors and all families have a child with asthma. He conducts pre-interviews, 16 weekly surveys, and post-interviews to investigate how participants understand and manage air pollution risks with the use of a sensor. While others have examined environmental justice implications of air pollution, few have assessed the environmental justice implications of a NAQMN. The methodological approach provides a transferable model for assessing NAQMNs elsewhere. This project advances understandings about the process of democratizing public access to air pollution information as well as how citizen science can inform decision making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

Fine particulate matter (PM2.5) air pollution contributes to adverse health outcomes of the heart and lungs, and children who have asthma are especially vulnerable to. In the United States, ambient PM2.5 air pollution is monitored by federal and state environmental agencies, though there are limitations to this type of monitoring. Due to a lack of authority and ability, indoor PM2.5 pollution is not regulated by the government. This leaves the public without full knowledge of their outdoor and indoor PM2.5 exposures. Emergent non-regulatory air quality monitoring networks (NAQMNs) are filling the void in exposure uncertainties as the low-cost sensors that make up NAQMNs, both outdoor and indoor, provide spatially and temporarily relevant PM2.5 estimates to the community through publicly accessible maps. As such, NAQMN sensors have the capacity to increase awareness of exposures and promote health-protective decision-making. However, sensor distribution in NAQMNs is not uniform, often underserving low socioeconomic status neighborhoods and communities of color. Moreover, even among those with sensor access, lower-income groups tend to experience higher levels of air pollution and are unable to respond to exposure information with the same capacity as higher-income groups. In this project, we conducted a mixed method intervention study to assess social disparities in the distribution of the Salt Lake County, Utah NAQMN and to understand how participatory sensing indoors and outdoors shaped the exposure experiences of parents with children who have asthma from an environmental justice perspective. To do so, we deployed 26 indoor and 27 outdoor PM2.5 sensors to households in the Salt Lake County area.

Intellectual Merit

The project contributes novel findings to environmental justice, risk society, and sociology scholarship while enhancing understandings of exposure experiences with participatory air quality sensing and decision making. While others have examined social inequalities in air pollution exposure, few have assessed social inequalities in NAQMNs from a university- versus privately-purchased perspective. In an assessment of all sensors, our quantitative results reveal more sensors per capita among higher-income and polluted tracts. Tracts with higher concentrations of Asian residents had reduced sensor access. When looking only at university-purchased sensors, we found that tracts with greater Hispanic/Latino/a immigrants had greater access. This reflects the university researchers’ deliberate distribution of sensors in high-need areas. Our approach illuminates how university-purchased sensors may enhance distributional environmental justice and our findings provide useful implications for enhancing equitable sensor distribution in NAQMNs. Qualitative research findings contribute to risk management research on decision-making. Findings suggest that PM2.5 sensors can raise awareness of outdoor and indoor exposures. Participatory sensing was a positive experience that kept parents informed about air quality and enhanced health-protective decision-making. Lower-income households in the study were exposed to greater indoor and outdoor PM2.5 levels on average than higher-income households. Additionally, overlooking ambient PM2.5 exposures was more common among lower-income households. More lower-income parents deemed the indoor sensor an effective participatory sensing tool than higher-income parents, which may reflect a greater need for immediate, actionable information. The ability of participatory sensing to encourage health-protective responsive actions is associated with income. Fewer lower-income households used air cleaning measures and engaged less in outdoor mitigation compared to higher-income households. These findings establish a cumulative burden on lower-income households regarding exposures and responsive actions.

Broader Impacts

Project outcomes include the equitable expansion of the Salt Lake County NAQMN in environmental justice communities of concern and among families impacted by asthma. The project findings are relevant to environmental policy nationally, and in Salt Lake County, which often exceeds national pollution standards. Findings from the project have been circulated via multiple outlets. We distributed results to NAQMN managers, study participants, public school and library personnel, public health experts, and policymakers of Salt Lake County. Analyses provided the basis for one under review paper, several manuscripts in progress, one dissertation, and one honors thesis as well as five presentations at local and national conferences and invited events. Education and research training opportunities were provided to graduate and undergraduate students—five of whom are from traditionally underrepresented backgrounds. The project integrated training of one doctoral student and six undergraduate students, and it provided the basis for one doctoral dissertation and one undergraduate senior thesis. Manuscripts involving data gathered during the intervention study will include undergraduate research assistants as coauthors. All undergraduate research assistants graduated from their respective degree programs. For the Co-PI, Mullen, a first-generation college student, this project helped them earn their doctorate degree and obtain a postdoctoral research associate position at Northeastern University in the Social Science Environmental Health Research Institute and will further facilitate their success as they strive to become a professor.
